meanings.definition: To seize or take possession of someone's property as security for payment of a debt or other obligation.
meanings.sent1: The landlord may distrain the tenant's belongings if rent is not paid.
meanings.sent2: The bank can distrain the car if the loan is not repaid on time.
meanings.sent3: The shopkeeper had to distrain the goods to ensure the customer paid.
meanings.sent4: The government can distrain assets to ensure tax compliance.
meanings.sent5: The sheriff had to distrain the cattle to cover the debt owed.

meanings.definition: To levy a distress on someone's property in order to enforce payment of a debt.
meanings.sent1: The court may distrain the house to collect the overdue fees.
meanings.sent2: The collector will distrain the furniture if the bill remains unpaid.
meanings.sent3: The farmer had to distrain the tractor to settle the debt.
meanings.sent4: The bank can distrain the property to recover the loan amount.
meanings.sent5: The authorities may distrain the goods to ensure compliance with the law.

meanings.definition: To seize or take possession of someone's property in order to compel payment of a debt.
meanings.sent1: The creditor may distrain the jewelry until the debt is cleared.
meanings.sent2: The landlord has the right to distrain the furniture for unpaid rent.
meanings.sent3: The company had to distrain the equipment to recover the owed amount.
meanings.sent4: The bank can distrain the assets to secure the loan repayment.
meanings.sent5: The authorities may distrain the property to ensure compliance with regulations.
